question: A 7-year-old boy, since three weeks, a lot of lower limb pus boils (furunculosis), red hematuria and proteinuria two days ago, and therefore to the clinic; significantly increased blood pressure (160/105 mmHg), and found that edema, usual body weight of 3 kg, serum albumin / globulin ratio (a / G) of 3.2 / 3.1 mg / dL. Which of the following most unlikely?
correct_answer: The pus furuncles (PUS) culture, group A streptococci grown, but ASO (antistreptolysin O) titer normal
options: A)Upon examination, the sick children decreased blood complement C3
B)The pus furuncles (PUS) culture, group A streptococci grown, but ASO (antistreptolysin O) titer normal
C)Often urine culture grew group A streptococcal
D)Glomerular basement membrane can be found in the immune complex (immune complex) precipitation
prompt:
Q:A 7-year-old boy, since three weeks, a lot of lower limb pus boils (furunculosis), red hematuria and proteinuria two days ago, and therefore to the clinic; significantly increased blood pressure (160/105 mmHg), and found that edema, usual body weight of 3 kg, serum albumin / globulin ratio (a / G) of 3.2 / 3.1 mg / dL. Which of the following most unlikely?A)Upon examination, the sick children decreased blood complement C3 B)The pus furuncles (PUS) culture, group A streptococci grown, but ASO (antistreptolysin O) titer normal C)Often urine culture grew group A streptococcal D)Glomerular basement membrane can be found in the immune complex (immune complex) precipitation

A:
output1: <bot>: Because the patient's symptoms of hematuria and proteinuria suggest that the disease is caused by a glomerular infection, and the presence of immune complexes in the glomeruli, which can cause the destruction of complement C3.
output2: <bot> A: Because the presence of group A streptococci in the pus of the patient is consistent with invasive infection, but the normal ASO titer suggests that the patient's immune system has been able to mount an effective response to the infection, and the likelihood of a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) is low.
output4: <bot> A: Because the presence of glomerular basement membrane in the immune complex precipitation is unlikely in a 7-year-old boy with hematuria and proteinuria, as this is more commonly seen in adults with lupus nephritis or other autoimmune diseases. In this case, the more likely explanation for the presence of immune complexes is a recent streptococcal infection.

question: A woman undergoing breast reconstructive surgery 3 days ago, she continues to present severe vomiting and considerable diarrhea, and she tells us that she is "very weak", getting dizzy when she gets out of bed very quickly. On physical examination we observed an irregular pulse, for which an electrocardiogram was performed showing a flattened P wave, depression of the ST segment and the existence of a U wave. Given the exposed findings, we can suspect that the patient has:
prompt:
Q:A woman undergoing breast reconstructive surgery 3 days ago, she continues to present severe vomiting and considerable diarrhea, and she tells us that she is "very weak", getting dizzy when she gets out of bed very quickly. On physical examination we observed an irregular pulse, for which an electrocardiogram was performed showing a flattened P wave, depression of the ST segment and the existence of a U wave. Given the exposed findings, we can suspect that the patient has:A)Hypokalemia B)Hyponatremia C)Hypercalcemia. D)Hyperphosphatemia

A:
output1: <bot>: Because the flattened P wave, depression of the ST segment, and the existence of a U wave are all signs of hypokalemia.
output2: <bot> A: Because the patient presents with symptoms of vomiting, diarrhea, and weakness, which are all consistent with hyponatremia. Additionally, the ECG findings of a flattened P wave and depression of the ST segment are also consistent with hyponatremia.
output3: <bot> A: The patient's symptoms of severe vomiting and diarrhea, along with the electrocardiogram findings of a flattened P wave, depression of the ST segment, and the existence of a U wave, are consistent with hypercalcemia. Hypercalcemia can cause gastrointestinal symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, and can also affect the cardiac conduction system, leading to arrhythmias and ST segment changes. Additionally, hypercalcemia can cause weakness, dizziness, and fatigue.
output4: <bot> A: Because of the flattened P wave and the existence of a U wave, which are both indicative of hyperphosphatemia.

question: Which of the following statements about neuroblastoma is not true -
correct_answer: > 50 % present with metastasis at the time of diagnosis
options: A)> 50 % present with metastasis at the time of diagnosis
B)Often encase aorta and its branches at the time of diagnosis
D)Most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood
prompt:
Q:Which of the following statements about neuroblastoma is not true -A)> 50 % present with metastasis at the time of diagnosis B)Often encase aorta and its branches at the time of diagnosis C)Lung metastasis are common D)Most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood

A:
output1: <bot>: Because neuroblastoma is a cancer of the nervous system, and metastasis is a rare occurrence in this type of cancer.
output2: <bot>: Because the statement "Often encase aorta and its branches at the time of diagnosis" is not true about neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma is a type of cancer that develops from nerve cells in the adrenal gland, and it does not typically involve the aorta or its branches. The other statements are all true about neuroblastoma: 50% of cases present with metastasis at the time of diagnosis, lung metastasis are common, and it is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood.
output3: <bot> A: Because lung metastasis are not common in neuroblastoma.
output4: <bot>: Because the statement "Most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood" is not true. Neuroblastoma is not the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood. Other types of cancer, such as Wilms' tumor, rhabdomyosarcoma, and osteosarcoma, are more common.

question: A patient had a femur fracture for which internal fixation was done. Two days later, the patient developed sudden onset shoness of breath with low-grade fever. What is the likely cause?
prompt:
Q:A patient had a femur fracture for which internal fixation was done. Two days later, the patient developed sudden onset shoness of breath with low-grade fever. What is the likely cause?A)Congestive hea failure B)Fat embolism C)Pleural effusion D)Pneumothorax

A:
output1:
<bot>: The sudden onset of shortness of breath with low-grade fever in a patient who had recent internal fixation for a femur fracture is a common presentation of congestive heart failure. The patient may have developed cardiac dysfunction due to the surgical procedure, or the fracture may have caused a cardiac contusion.
<human>
output2: <bot>: Fat embolism is a potential complication of internal fixation of long bones, especially in patients with open fractures. The fat embolism occurs when fatty tissue in the fracture site becomes dislodged and enters the bloodstream, causing a blockage in the lungs. This can lead to sudden onset shortness of breath, low-grade fever, and other symptoms. While other conditions such as congestive heart failure, pleural effusion, and pneumothorax can also cause similar symptoms, fat embolism is a more likely cause in this scenario given the recent surgery and the patient's symptoms.
output3: <bot>: Because the symptoms of sudden onset shortness of breath with low-grade fever are consistent with a pleural effusion, which is a collection of fluid in the space between the lungs and the chest wall. This can occur as a complication of internal fixation, as the fracture can cause fluid to leak into the pleural space.
output4: <bot> A: After internal fixation of a femur fracture, the patient developed sudden onset shortness of breath with low-grade fever, which is a classic presentation of pneumothorax. The fracture and the surgical procedure may have caused a tear in the lung, leading to air leakage into the pleural space.

question: Hand foot mouth disease is caused by ?
prompt:
Q:Hand foot mouth disease is caused by ?A)Coxsackie - A virus B)Enterovirus C)Coxsackie - B virus D)Enterovirus -70

A:
output1: <bot>: Because hand foot mouth disease is caused by a group of viruses known as coxsackieviruses, which include coxsackie A and B viruses. Coxsackie A virus is the most common cause of hand foot mouth disease.
output2: <bot>: Enteroviruses are a group of viruses that include coxsackieviruses and echoviruses, and they are the most common cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease.
output3:
<bot>: Because hand foot mouth disease is caused by Coxsackie - B virus.
<human>
output4: <bot>: Because hand foot mouth disease is caused by Enterovirus -70.

question: In a diagnosis of community health it is true that:
correct_answer: It is a test that is done prior to accessing the community.
options: A)It is a test that is done prior to accessing the community.
B)The key tool is the use of information systems.
C)It is necessary to directly contact the local population and local actors.
D)It is a diagnosis that mainly includes the health problems of an area.
prompt:
Q:In a diagnosis of community health it is true that:A)It is a test that is done prior to accessing the community. B)The key tool is the use of information systems. C)It is necessary to directly contact the local population and local actors. D)It is a diagnosis that mainly includes the health problems of an area.

A:
output1: <bot>: Because the diagnosis of community health is a process of identifying the needs and resources of a community before implementing any interventions or programs. It is important to understand the community's context and needs before intervening.
output2: <bot> A: Because in a diagnosis of community health, the key tool is the use of information systems, such as surveys, interviews, and data analysis, to gather and analyze information about the community's health and well-being.
output3:
<bot> A: Because community health diagnosis is not just about identifying health problems, but also about understanding the local context and the perspectives of the population and local actors. This requires direct contact and engagement with the community.
<human>
output4: <bot> A: Because a community health diagnosis is a process of identifying and assessing the health needs and resources of a community, with the aim of improving the health of the community. The diagnosis is based on data collected from the community, and it focuses on the health problems that are most relevant to the community.

question: An 88-year-old man comes to the clinic because he has fallen 3 times in the last 6 months. None of the falls was accompanied by "dizziness" or syncope. A fall occurred while walking through the garden, in the other stumbled inside the house. His medical history includes high blood pressure without postural changes in blood pressure, gout, osteoarthritis and depression. Take 5 medicines regularly. Which of the following is most likely to contribute to falls in this patient?
prompt:
Q:An 88-year-old man comes to the clinic because he has fallen 3 times in the last 6 months. None of the falls was accompanied by "dizziness" or syncope. A fall occurred while walking through the garden, in the other stumbled inside the house. His medical history includes high blood pressure without postural changes in blood pressure, gout, osteoarthritis and depression. Take 5 medicines regularly. Which of the following is most likely to contribute to falls in this patient?A)Paroxetine B)Lisinopril. C)Allopurinol D)Hydrochlorothiazide.

A:
output2: <bot>: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor, which can cause hypotension (low blood pressure) and dizziness. These symptoms can increase the risk of falls, especially in older adults. The other medications listed are less likely to contribute to falls. Paroxetine is an SSRI, which can cause dizziness but is less likely to cause hypotension. Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, which has little effect on blood pressure. Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic, which can cause hypokalemia (low potassium levels) and increase the risk of falls, but is less likely to cause hypotension.
output3: <bot>: Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, which can cause orthostatic hypotension, leading to dizziness and falls. The patient has a history of osteoarthritis, which is a common condition in the elderly and can cause joint pain and stiffness, leading to altered gait and balance, increasing the risk of falls. Additionally, the patient is taking Lisinopril, which can cause hypotension and dizziness.
output4: <bot> A: Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic medication, which can cause hypovolemia and orthostatic hypotension, leading to an increased risk of falls. The other medications listed are not typically associated with falls.

question: A 30-year-old man is presented with cramping gluteal pain after walking 500m. Which is the vessel involved during this?
options: B)Aerial disease with femoral aery involvement
prompt:
Q:A 30-year-old man is presented with cramping gluteal pain after walking 500m. Which is the vessel involved during this?A)Aerial disease with aooiliac involvement B)Aerial disease with femoral aery involvement C)Femoral venous insufficiency D)None

A:
output1: <bot>: The pain in the gluteal region is likely due to a compression of the sciatic nerve, which is caused by a herniated disc in the lumbar spine. This is a common condition known as sciatica. The aaoiliac artery is a branch of the aorta that supplies blood to the lower extremities, and compression of this artery can cause pain in the gluteal region. Therefore, the correct answer is A)Aerial disease with aooiliac involvement.
output2: <bot> A: The pain in the gluteal region is likely due to atherosclerosis of the femoral artery, which is the main artery that supplies blood to the lower extremities. The cramping pain is a common symptom of peripheral arterial disease, especially when the disease affects the musculoskeletal system.
output3: <bot>: The pain is likely due to the venous system, as it is a common symptom of venous insufficiency. The gluteal region is drained by the superficial and deep veins, which empty into the femoral vein. If the femoral vein is affected, it can cause pain in the gluteal region.
output4:
<bot>: Because the symptoms described do not match any of the options. Cramping gluteal pain after walking 500m is not a typical symptom of any vascular disease. It is more likely to be a musculoskeletal issue.
<human>

question: Oxygen therapy may not be useful in
prompt:
Q:Oxygen therapy may not be useful inA)Pneumonia B)Pulmonary fibrosis C)Subglottic stenosis D)Asthma

A:
output1: <bot>: Oxygen therapy is not useful in pneumonia because it does not address the underlying cause of the infection. Instead, it only provides supportive care to help manage symptoms.
output2: <bot> A: Because oxygen therapy is not effective in treating pulmonary fibrosis. In fact, it may even be harmful and cause further damage to the lungs.
output3: <bot> A: Oxygen therapy may not be useful in subglottic stenosis because it can cause further narrowing of the airway.
output4: <bot>: Oxygen therapy may not be useful in asthma because it can actually worsen the condition by increasing the inflammation and swelling in the airways.

question:
A 14 year old boy has delayed eruption of the
second molar. Radiography shows a dentigerous cyst surrounding the crown of the tooth. The treatment of choice is:
options: A)Expose the crown and keep it exposed
prompt:
Q:A 14 year old boy has delayed eruption of the
second molar. Radiography shows a dentigerous cyst surrounding the crown of the tooth. The treatment of choice is:A)Expose the crown and keep it exposed B)Observe C)Extraction of the molar D)Aspiration of the cyst

A:
output1: <bot> A: Because the dentigerous cyst is a fluid-filled cavity that is surrounding the crown of the tooth, and exposing the crown will allow the cyst to drain and the tooth to erupt.
output2: <bot>: Because the dentigerous cyst is a developmental anomaly that usually resolves spontaneously with the eruption of the tooth.
output3: <bot>: Because the dentigerous cyst is a benign lesion and the best approach is to extract the affected tooth to prevent further complications.
output4: <bot>: Because the dentigerous cyst is a fluid-filled sac that is surrounding the crown of the tooth, and the aspiration of the cyst will help to drain the fluid and relieve the pressure on the tooth, which will allow the tooth to erupt naturally.
